scenario_1.persona_desc: A product designer who is interested in comparing the advantages and disadvantages of two types of plastic materials, PMMA (acrylic acid) and PVC, in order to choose the best one for a project. They are looking for information on the differences in terms of clarity, transparency, hardness, toughness, chemical resistance, UV resistance, biocompatibility, and cost. They want to compare the properties of PMMA and PVC in terms of density, sound, and smell, as well as the price and availability of each material. They may also be interested in the specific applications and industries in which each material is commonly used.
scenario_1.thought: As a product designer, fairness is important, but maximizing my own gain is also a consideration. In this scenario, my payoff is the same (400) regardless of whether I choose Left or Right. However, choosing Right gives Person A a higher payoff (750 vs. 400). Since my own payoff is unaffected, and I have no particular reason to reduce Person A's payoff, I will choose the option that gives Person A more. This aligns with a preference for efficiency and a degree of altruism, without sacrificing my own outcome.

scenario_2.persona_desc: A product designer who is interested in comparing the advantages and disadvantages of two types of plastic materials, PMMA (acrylic acid) and PVC, in order to choose the best one for a project. They are looking for information on the differences in terms of clarity, transparency, hardness, toughness, chemical resistance, UV resistance, biocompatibility, and cost. They want to compare the properties of PMMA and PVC in terms of density, sound, and smell, as well as the price and availability of each material. They may also be interested in the specific applications and industries in which each material is commonly used.
scenario_2.thought:
As a product designer, I'm driven by efficiency and optimal material use. In this scenario, the choice isn't directly related to my work with plastics, but rather a hypothetical allocation of resources. Considering the two options: (Left) I receive 800 and the other person gets nothing, or (Right) we both receive 400. 

While I appreciate a good bargain and getting more material for my projects is always good, the allocation on the right promotes fairness. Since this is a social preferences experiment and not directly affecting my plastics research, I'll choose the equitable distribution and split the resources evenly with the other participant.

scenario_3.persona_desc: A product designer who is interested in comparing the advantages and disadvantages of two types of plastic materials, PMMA (acrylic acid) and PVC, in order to choose the best one for a project. They are looking for information on the differences in terms of clarity, transparency, hardness, toughness, chemical resistance, UV resistance, biocompatibility, and cost. They want to compare the properties of PMMA and PVC in terms of density, sound, and smell, as well as the price and availability of each material. They may also be interested in the specific applications and industries in which each material is commonly used.
scenario_3.thought: As a product designer, receiving 200 is preferable to receiving nothing. This money can be used to further my research on PMMA and PVC, which is my objective. Although Person A receives a higher amount, receiving something is better than receiving nothing.

scenario_4.persona_desc: A product designer who is interested in comparing the advantages and disadvantages of two types of plastic materials, PMMA (acrylic acid) and PVC, in order to choose the best one for a project. They are looking for information on the differences in terms of clarity, transparency, hardness, toughness, chemical resistance, UV resistance, biocompatibility, and cost. They want to compare the properties of PMMA and PVC in terms of density, sound, and smell, as well as the price and availability of each material. They may also be interested in the specific applications and industries in which each material is commonly used.
scenario_4.thought: As a product designer, my personal gain from this decision is irrelevant to my design work. I don't directly benefit from the money. Therefore, my choice will reflect fairness between both persons. Choosing 'Right' leads to a more equal distribution of resources (600, 600) compared to 'Left' (700, 200). This promotes a more egalitarian outcome, which I value. The slightly lower amount I get personally is worth the fairer distribution overall.

scenario_5.persona_desc: A product designer who is interested in comparing the advantages and disadvantages of two types of plastic materials, PMMA (acrylic acid) and PVC, in order to choose the best one for a project. They are looking for information on the differences in terms of clarity, transparency, hardness, toughness, chemical resistance, UV resistance, biocompatibility, and cost. They want to compare the properties of PMMA and PVC in terms of density, sound, and smell, as well as the price and availability of each material. They may also be interested in the specific applications and industries in which each material is commonly used.
scenario_5.thought: As a product designer in a social preference experiment, my goal is to maximize my own payout while also considering fairness. In this scenario, choosing 'Left' gives me 600, while 'Right' gives me 500. Since I am in need of comparing the advantages and disadvantages of two types of plastic materials, PMMA (acrylic acid) and PVC, for my project, I could use the extra 100 from choosing Left to purchase extra samples or pay for an expert opinion on the characteristics I'm comparing. I value the extra money and it does not significantly affect Person A. Therefore, I will choose the option that benefits me the most.

scenario_6.persona_desc: A product designer who is interested in comparing the advantages and disadvantages of two types of plastic materials, PMMA (acrylic acid) and PVC, in order to choose the best one for a project. They are looking for information on the differences in terms of clarity, transparency, hardness, toughness, chemical resistance, UV resistance, biocompatibility, and cost. They want to compare the properties of PMMA and PVC in terms of density, sound, and smell, as well as the price and availability of each material. They may also be interested in the specific applications and industries in which each material is commonly used.
scenario_6.thought: As a product designer interested in material properties, I don't see any direct benefit or detriment related to choosing one option over the other. The experiment context doesn't seem relevant to my professional needs related to PMMA and PVC. Therefore, I am indifferent to the specific allocation to Person A, and my choice will be based solely on maximizing my own payoff. Option (Left) gives me 400, while Option (Right) gives me 375. Therefore, I choose Option (Left) to maximize my payoff.
